Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Parietal Cortex and the Transformation of Spatial Cognition into Action
Award.AbstractNarration: Humans and animals alike need to connect where they are in the world to the best choice of action to take. Much is known about brain mechanisms by which control of the musculature is accomplished as well as brain mechanisms by which an organism's position in an environment is encoded. How these control systems interact, however, is unknown. Recent findings suggest that the posterior parietal cortex is a brain structure that, by virtue of both its anatomy and physiology, can coordinate control of the musculature according to the spatial position that an organism occupies. This project will combine novel behavioral tasks, multiple single-neuron recording techniques, and temporary (focal) brain-inactivation techniques to determine if this is, indeed, the case. Furthermore, the project will determine the coding mechanism whereby perception of position in the world is transformed into a plan of action. The experiments are expected to show that the parietal cortex is responsible for the generation of "action-planning" signals that are found within the premotor cortex and that parietal cortex activity pulls sensory and motor systems into a common network such that sensory inputs can guide motor control in a fluid, efficient fashion. The work's importance lies in identifying the neural machinery responsible for utilizing complex cognitive abilities (mapping one's position in the world) to control the senses and musculature, thereby allowing for intelligent behavior. The results will be of importance to the further development of autonomous robots that utilize simulated neural networks and to the study of neurological disorders, such as autism, where efficient sequencing of actions based on environmental stimuli appears to be deficient. Results of the work will be disseminated through scientific publication and will form the basis for outreach projects wherein high school students are given the chance to practice neuroscience in a real-world setting.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project addressed how multiple regions of the brain interact to yield a transformation of spatial information into actions that define navigational decisions.  More specifically, the project addressed how the brain encodes the myriad number of spatial relationships that must be considered for intelligent navigation to take place within what we call "path networks".  Path networks simply refers to multiple pathways that are interconnected and oriented to each other in either simple or complex fashion (as in the city streets of a city). While prior work in the field had discovered "place", "head direction", and "grid" neurons whose activity signifies the location and/or orientation of an animal in the environment, this project discovered several new forms of such spatial mapping.  The basis of the project began with the discovery of "route encoding" wherein activity in the posterior parietal cortex signifies the location of an animal within a route (such as a L-shaped route or zig-zag shaped route) irrespective of the location of the route in the environment. A first major discovery under the grant was the finding that the retrosplenial cortex, to that point a brain region never recorded during navigation, exhibits activity dynamics consistent with relating position along a known route to the position of the animal in the environment. Thus, the retrosplenial cortex, as suggested by lesion studies, is key to memory processes wherein locations in the environment are associated with specific routes to goal locations. At the same time, another publication based on project work, demonstrated, for the first time, a set of neurons whose activity is spatially periodic, waxing and waning over different frequencies as an animal moves along a known path. An emergent property of this periodicity is that retrosplenial neuron populations map not only the location of the animal in the environment, but also the distance to all other locations on a route.  A second key discovery was the finding that another brain region never studied in an actual navigation task, the subiculum, was found to contain "axis" neurons that are active when the animal moves in one direction or that directions exact (180-degree) opposite.  Axis neurons thus map the orientation, relative to the larger environment, of particular pathways through the environment.  These are complemented by neurons which exhibit sensitivity to the "structural analogy" of multiple locations in a path network.  For example, city networks with highly regular structure, such as Manhattan, contain multiple locations, such as NW corners, that have structural analogy.  Large populations of subiculum neurons have activity specific to the animal's presence in multiple locations that bear analogy to each other. In this way, the subiculum was found to encode the very structural layout of paths within an environment. This development takes the field of spatial mapping in a very novel direction. Finally, we are soon to publish a work on the medial precentral cortex, one of the main targets of the project. This area, we find, contains a large poplation of neurons whose activity either encodes specific navigational actions (such as L vs R turns) or the planned (upcoming) action of the animal.  As this region receives strong inputs from posterior parietal cortex and retrosplenial cortex, we identify the medial precentral cortex as the key brain region mediating a transition of spatial information into logical navigation decisions. Together, these results greatly expand our knowledge of how the very complex problem of navigation and location awareness is handled across a network of interconnected brain regions.
